dt: {bc}to prevent from doing, exhibiting, or expressing something
{bc}to moderate or limit the force, effect, development, or full exercise of

pt: {sc}restrain{/sc} {sc}check{/sc} {sc}curb{/sc} {sc}bridle{/sc} mean to hold back from or control in doing something. {sc}restrain{/sc} suggests holding back by force or persuasion from acting or from going to extremes.
{sc}check{/sc} implies restraining or impeding a progress, activity, or impetus.
{sc}curb{/sc} suggests an abrupt or drastic checking.
{sc}bridle{/sc} implies keeping under control by subduing or holding in.

pt.t: {it}bridle{/it} an impulse to throw the book down

et: Middle English {it}restraynen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}restreindre{/it}, from Latin {it}restringere{/it} to restrain, restrict, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}stringere{/it} to bind tight {ma}{mat|strain|}{/ma}
shortdef: to prevent from doing, exhibiting, or expressing something
to limit, restrict, or keep under control
to moderate or limit the force, effect, development, or full exercise of
